title: Knifeman allegedly stabbed police officers at a Caltex petrol station in Toronto, near Newcastle
text:
A knifeman charged after a police officer after stabbing another following a wild road rage attack at a service station.

Officers were called to a Caltex petrol station in in Toronto, south of Newcastle in New South Wales, on Sunday after reports a man was armed with two knives.

When police arrived they saw the man slashing another car's tyres following a road rage incident.

Shocking footage shows the shirtless man in a violent tussle with the two officers as they desperately try to subdue him using batons and pepper spray.

Shocking footage showed the shirtless man in a violent tussle with the two officers who tried desperately to subdue him

While waiting for police backup to arrive, four witnesses pinned the alleged offender to the ground and handcuffed him

After slashing at one officer, another cop is seen running for his life, only to be chased by the knife-wielding man.

The alleged offender stabbed one officer in the leg and slashed the other officer's hand.

When capsicum spray and batons didn't bring the man under control, police were forced to draw their guns.

They opened fire on the man but missed.

'They were all aimed at either the lower body or off to the side just to scare him,' witness Joel Mr Roberts told 9 News.

While waiting for police backup to arrive, Mr Roberts and his three friends pinned the alleged offender to the ground and handcuffed him.

'Myself and two others ran in and grabbed the bloke and held him on the ground until other cops arrived,' he said.

'Me and a couple of other guys were actually the ones who took him down'.

The man was arrested after backup police arrived on the scene.

The two injured responding officers were rushed to John Hunter Hospital for surgery on serious stab wounds. Both are recovering in a stable condition.

A 25-year-old man was arrested after he allegedly stabbed two police at a Caltex petrol station in Newcatsle

The group of men who witnessed the incident were traveling on a bus on their way to perform community service when they saw the alleged offender holding knives.

'I had got out of the bus to get some air when this bloke focused on me and said: 'where is my ounce, where is my ounce',' one of the men, Joel Roberts told the Daily Telegraph.

'I thought "what is this bloke on about" and then I saw the knife in his hand.'

Mr Roberts and a number of other people ran 50m to Toronto Police Station where they alerted officers to what they had seen.
